refnamediv.refpurpose: Controls the keyboard/mouse pointer grabs and a set of GdkScreens

refsynopsisdiv.title: Synopsis

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para:
GdkDisplay objects purpose are two fold:
To grab/ungrab keyboard focus and mouse pointer
To manage and provide information about the GdkScreen(s) available for this GdkDisplay

GdkDisplay objects are the GDK representation of the X Display which can be described as a workstation consisting of a keyboard a pointing device (such as a mouse) and one or more screens. It is used to open and keep track of various GdkScreen objects currently instanciated by the application. It is also used to grab and release the keyboard and the mouse pointer.

refsect2.title: GdkDisplay
refsect2.para: The GdkDisplay struct is the GDK representation of an X display. All its fields are private and should not be accessed directly.

listitem.simpara: the name of the display to open
a GdkDisplay, or NULL if the display could not be opened.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_get_default ()
refsect2.para: Gets the default GdkDisplay. This is a convenience function for gdk_display_manager_get_default_display (gdk_display_manager_get()).

listitem.simpara: a GdkDisplay, or NULL if there is no default display.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_get_name ()
refsect2.para: Gets the name of the display.

listitem.simpara: a string representing the display name. This string is owned by GDK and should not be modified or freed.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_get_n_screens ()
refsect2.para: Gets the number of screen managed by the display.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_get_screen ()
refsect2.para: Returns a screen object for one of the screens of the display.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_get_default_screen ()
refsect2.para: Get the default GdkScreen for display.

listitem.simpara: the default GdkScreen object for display

refsect2.title: gdk_display_pointer_is_grabbed ()
refsect2.para: Test if the pointer is grabbed.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if an active X pointer grab is in effect

refsect2.title: gdk_display_beep ()
refsect2.para: Emits a short beep on display

refsect2.title: gdk_display_sync ()
refsect2.para: Flushes any requests queued for the windowing system and waits until all requests have been handled. This is often used for making sure that the display is synchronized with the current state of the program. Calling gdk_display_sync() before gdk_error_trap_pop() makes sure that any errors generated from earlier requests are handled before the error trap is removed.
This is most useful for X11. On windowing systems where requests are handled synchronously, this function will do nothing.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_flush ()
refsect2.para: Flushes any requests queued for the windowing system; this happens automatically when the main loop blocks waiting for new events, but if your application is drawing without returning control to the main loop, you may need to call this function explicitely. A common case where this function needs to be called is when an application is executing drawing commands from a thread other than the thread where the main loop is running.
This is most useful for X11. On windowing systems where requests are handled synchronously, this function will do nothing.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_close ()
refsect2.para: Closes the connection to the windowing system for the given display, and cleans up associated resources.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_list_devices ()
refsect2.para: Returns the list of available input devices attached to display. The list is statically allocated and should not be freed.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_get_event ()
refsect2.para: Gets the next GdkEvent to be processed for display, fetching events from the windowing system if necessary.

listitem.simpara: the next GdkEvent to be processed, or NULL if no events are pending. The returned GdkEvent should be freed with gdk_event_free().

refsect2.title: gdk_display_peek_event ()
refsect2.para: Gets a copy of the first GdkEvent in the display's event queue, without removing the event from the queue. (Note that this function will not get more events from the windowing system. It only checks the events that have already been moved to the GDK event queue.)

listitem.simpara: a copy of the first GdkEvent on the event queue, or NULL if no events are in the queue. The returned GdkEvent should be freed with gdk_event_free().

refsect2.title: gdk_display_put_event ()
refsect2.para: Appends a copy of the given event onto the front of the event queue for display.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_add_client_message_filter ()
refsect2.programlisting: void gdk_display_add_client_message_filter (GdkDisplay *display, GdkAtom message_type, GdkFilterFunc func, gpointer data);
refsect2.para: Adds a filter to be called when X ClientMessage events are received. See gdk_window_add_filter() if you are interested in filtering other types of events.

listitem.simpara: a GdkDisplay for which this message filter applies
the type of ClientMessage events to receive. This will be checked against the message_type field of the XClientMessage event struct.
the function to call to process the event.
user data to pass to func.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_set_double_click_time ()
refsect2.para: Sets the double click time (two clicks within this time interval count as a double click and result in a GDK_2BUTTON_PRESS event). Applications should not set this, it is a global user-configured setting.

listitem.simpara: double click time in milliseconds (thousandths of a second)

refsect2.title: gdk_display_set_double_click_distance ()
refsect2.para: Sets the double click distance (two clicks within this distance count as a double click and result in a GDK_2BUTTON_PRESS event). See also gdk_display_set_double_click_time(). Applications should not set this, it is a global user-configured setting.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_get_pointer ()
refsect2.programlisting: void gdk_display_get_pointer (GdkDisplay *display, GdkScreen **screen, gint *x, gint *y, GdkModifierType *mask);
refsect2.para: Gets the current location of the pointer and the current modifier mask for a given display.

listitem.simpara: location to store the screen that the cursor is on, or NULL.
location to store root window X coordinate of pointer, or NULL.
location to store root window Y coordinate of pointer, or NULL.
location to store current modifier mask, or NULL

refsect2.title: gdk_display_get_window_at_pointer ()
refsect2.para: Obtains the window underneath the mouse pointer, returning the location of the pointer in that window in win_x, win_y for screen. Returns NULL if the window under the mouse pointer is not known to GDK (for example, belongs to another application).

listitem.simpara: return location for x coordinate of the pointer location relative to the window origin, or NULL
return location for y coordinate of the pointer location relative & to the window origin, or NULL
the window under the mouse pointer, or NULL

refsect2.title: GdkDisplayPointerHooks
refsect2.para: A table of pointers to functions for getting quantities related to the current pointer position. Each GdkDisplay has a table of this type, which can be set using gdk_display_set_pointer_hooks().
This is only useful for such low-level tools as an event recorder. Applications should never have any reason to use this facility

listitem.simpara: Obtains the current pointer position and modifier state. The position is given in coordinates relative to the window containing the pointer, which is returned in window.
Obtains the window underneath the mouse pointer. Current pointer position and modifier state are returned in x, y and mask. The position is given in coordinates relative to window.

Obtains the window underneath the mouse pointer, returning the location of that window in win_x, win_y. Returns NULL if the window under the mouse pointer is not known to GDK (for example, belongs to another application).

refsect2.title: gdk_display_set_pointer_hooks ()
refsect2.para: This function allows for hooking into the operation of getting the current location of the pointer on a particular display. This is only useful for such low-level tools as an event recorder. Applications should never have any reason to use this facility.

listitem.simpara: a table of pointers to functions for getting quantities related to the current pointer position, or NULL to restore the default table.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_warp_pointer ()
refsect2.programlisting: void gdk_display_warp_pointer (GdkDisplay *display, GdkScreen *screen, gint x, gint y);
refsect2.para: Warps the pointer of display to the point x,y on the screen screen, unless the pointer is confined to a window by a grab, in which case it will be moved as far as allowed by the grab. Warping the pointer creates events as if the user had moved the mouse instantaneously to the destination.

Note that the pointer should normally be under the control of the user. This function was added to cover some rare use cases like keyboard navigation support for the color picker in the GtkColorSelectionDialog.

listitem.simpara: the screen of display to warp the pointer to
the x coordinate of the destination
the y coordinate of the destination

refsect2.title: gdk_display_supports_cursor_color ()
refsect2.para: Returns TRUE if multicolored cursors are supported on display. Otherwise, cursors have only a forground and a background color.

listitem.simpara: whether cursors can have multiple colors.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_supports_cursor_alpha ()
refsect2.para: Returns TRUE if cursors can use an 8bit alpha channel on display. Otherwise, cursors are restricted to bilevel alpha (i.e. a mask).

listitem.simpara: whether cursors can have alpha channels.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_get_default_cursor_size ()
refsect2.para: Returns the default size to use for cursors on display.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_get_maximal_cursor_size ()
refsect2.para: Gets the maximal size to use for cursors on display.

listitem.simpara: the return location for the maximal cursor width
the return location for the maximal cursor height

refsect2.title: gdk_display_get_default_group ()
refsect2.para: Returns the default group leader window for all toplevel windows on display. This window is implicitly created by GDK. See gdk_window_set_group().

listitem.simpara: The default group leader window for display

refsect2.title: gdk_display_supports_selection_notification ()
refsect2.para: Returns whether GdkEventOwnerChange events will be sent when the owner of a selection changes.

listitem.simpara: whether GdkEventOwnerChange events will be sent.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_request_selection_notification ()
refsect2.para: Request GdkEventOwnerChange events for ownership changes of the selection named by the given atom.

listitem.simpara: the GdkAtom naming the selection for which ownership change notification is requested
whether GdkEventOwnerChange events will be sent.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_supports_clipboard_persistence ()
refsect2.para: Returns whether the speicifed display supports clipboard persistance; i.e. if it's possible to store the clipboard data after an application has quit. On X11 this checks if a clipboard daemon is running.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if the display supports clipboard persistance.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_store_clipboard ()
refsect2.programlisting: void gdk_display_store_clipboard (GdkDisplay *display, GdkWindow *clipboard_window, guint32 time_, const GdkAtom *targets, gint n_targets);
refsect2.para:
Issues a request to the clipboard manager to store the clipboard data. On X11, this is a special program that works according to the freedesktop clipboard specification, available at
http://www.freedesktop.org/Standards/clipboard-manager-spec.

listitem.simpara: a GdkWindow belonging to the clipboard owner
an array of targets that should be saved, or NULL if all available targets should be saved.

refsect2.title: gdk_display_supports_shapes ()
refsect2.para: Returns TRUE if gdk_window_shape_combine_mask() can be used to create shaped windows on display.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if shaped windows are supported

refsect2.title: gdk_display_supports_input_shapes ()
refsect2.para: Returns TRUE if gdk_window_input_shape_combine_mask() can be used to modify the input shape of windows on display.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if windows with modified input shape are supported

refsect2.title: gdk_display_supports_composite ()
refsect2.para: Returns TRUE if gdk_window_set_composited() can be used to redirect drawing on the window using compositing.
Currently this only works on X11 with XComposite and XDamage extensions available.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if windows may be composited.

refsect2.title: The "closed" signal
refsect2.programlisting: void user_function (GdkDisplay *display, gboolean is_error, gpointer user_data) : Run Last
refsect2.para: The ::closed signal is emitted when the connection to the windowing system for display is closed.

listitem.simpara: the object on which the signal is emitted
TRUE if the display was closed due to an error
user data set when the signal handler was connected.
